sailpoint.workflow

Class WorkflowContext

  • java.lang.Object
    • sailpoint.workflow.WorkflowContext
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    sailpoint.tools.VariableResolver

    public class WorkflowContext
extends java.lang.Object
implements sailpoint.tools.VariableResolver
    Runtime information maintained by the workflow engine as it advances through a workflow case. Passed into rules and scripts in case they need to know where they are, and passed to every method in the registered WorkflowHandler.

      • getWorkflowLaunch

        public WorkflowLaunch getWorkflowLaunch()
        Returns the WorkflowLaunch object. This is valid only when the workflow is being launched for the first time, it is currently intended only for use by the addLaunchMessage library method to set things for display in the UI after launch.

        This is always inherited, if you are in a subcase context, walk up the stack to the root context.

      • setWorkflowLaunch

        public void setWorkflowLaunch(WorkflowLaunch wfl)

      • isForeground

        public boolean isForeground()
        Return true if this is a foreground session. Usually this means you are in a UI request thread whereas background means you are in a background task thread.

      • isTransient

        public boolean isTransient()
        Return true if this is a transient workflow session.

      • getTaskResult

        public TaskResult getTaskResult()
                         throws GeneralException
        Returns the TaskResult associated with the WorkflowCase. A TaskResult is only created for the root case, so if you are in a subcase walk up. There will always be a result, possibly a transient one if the case has not yet been saved.
        Throws:
        GeneralException

      • getRootWorkflowCase

        public WorkflowCase getRootWorkflowCase()
        Walk up the subcase hierarchy until we find the root case. This is what you need for storing WorkItems since only the root case is persisted as an addressable object.

      • getWorkflow

        public Workflow getWorkflow()
        Returns the workflow definition. This is a copy of the persistent definition stored inside the case.

      • getStepArguments

        public Attributes<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> getStepArguments()
        Return a map containing only the values of explicit Step arguments. Normally the value returned by WorkflowContext.getArguments() has a merger of all the worklfow variables plus any values defined in this step. This is convenient for scriptlets since they often want to reference workflow variables without having to define explicit s or call wf.get.

        This is less intersting for handler class calls, since we are in Java the methods can more easily make the appropriate calls. We have historically passed them everything though.

        Occasionally though the handler method needs to pass the values of the arguments along to something else, as when launching a task or scheduling a workflow request. In these cases we cannot let all the workflow variables plus various unserializable things stuck in the arg map to get through.

        This method will return a map contain only the values of s defined in this step.

      • getApprovalArguments

        public Attributes<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> getApprovalArguments()
        Similar to getStepArguments, but returns the arguments Associated with a Step's approval.
        Returns:
        Map representing the resolved arguments

      • queueProcessLog

        public void queueProcessLog(ProcessLog pl)
        When a workflow is transient ProcessLog entries are not saved until the workflow is persisted. ProcessLog entries that are generated while transient should be queued in case they need to be saved later.

      • setArgument

        public void setArgument(java.lang.String name,
               java.lang.Object value)
        Add something to the local arguments map. This is not called put() so we can be clearer about what this does.

      • setVariable

        public void setVariable(java.lang.String name,
               java.lang.Object value)
        Set a workflow variable. This is not necessary but saves a few lines in scripts.

      • getVariable

        public java.lang.Object getVariable(java.lang.String name)
        Get a workflow variable. This is not necessary but saves a few lines in scripts.

      • get

        public java.lang.Object get(java.lang.String name)
        Return the value of a context argument. These are built dynamically during evaluation. It will at minimum contain the standard args: wfcontext, handler, workflow, etc. and the values of all declared workflow variables. In addition it can include the values of Step and Approval Args.

        NOTE: For backward compatibility with old workflows that did not declare variables, we will look in the Workflow._variables map if we do not find an entry in the context's map. This means that if you have an Arg that sets something to null, it cannot override a workflow variable.

      • getString

        public java.lang.String getString(java.lang.String name)
        Uses WorkflowContext.get(java.lang.String) to find a value and coerces it to a string.

      • getBoolean

        public boolean getBoolean(java.lang.String name)
        Uses WorkflowContext.get(java.lang.String) to find a value and coerces it to a boolean.

      • getInt

        public int getInt(java.lang.String name)
        Uses WorkflowContext.get(java.lang.String) to find a value and coerces it to an int.

      • getWorkItemPriority

        public WorkItem.Level getWorkItemPriority()
        Returns the WorkItem.Level that should be set on any WorkItems created by this WorkflowContext's Workflow.
